{{ page.title }}

Getting started

{{ site.name }} comes with some handy tools, that allow to test the code, to build the project for repositories like NPM or Bower, or generate the documentation.
All this is made possible with Gulp, in addiction to many other projects listed on the credits page.

Gulp is a build system which relies on a set of tasks. Those tasks can perform all kinds stuff on the project.
{{ site.name }} has the following tasks:

  • Info task
  • Init task
  • Test task
  • Serve task
  • Build task
  • Doc task
  • CI task

Info task

The info task just prints info about the project on the console.
Just run:


gulp info

Init task

The init task fetches latest libs from Bower, and copies them to the test/ folder. The copied libs are used for testing with PhantomJS.
Just run:


bower update
gulp init

Test task

The test task runs the tests located in the test folder of the project.
The tests are run 3 times:

  • in Node.js
  • in a browser (PhantomJS), using AMD modules
  • in a browser (PhantomJS), using globals

Just run:

gulp test

Build task

The build task does the following:

  • Runs the test task, and if it is successful, begins the build task
  • Lints the code with JSHint
  • Analyzes the code with JSCS
  • Updates version from package.json to bower.json and the source
  • if the 3 previous tasks succeed, copies the source to the dist folder twice (1 identic to source, 1 minified)

Just run:

gulp build

Doc task

Please check the page dedicated to this task!

The doc task does the following:

  • Runs the build task, and if it is successful, begins the doc task
  • Creates the gh-pages skeleton
  • Imports assets for gh-pages from Bower dependencies
  • Creates JSDoc documentation (in gh-pages)
  • Creates changelog (in gh-pages)
  • Creates code coverage (in gh-pages)
  • Creates dependency trees (in gh-pages)
  • Gzip the sitemap (in gh-pages)
  • Compiles docs form gh-pages (using Jekyll)

Just run:

gulp doc

CI task

The ci task is mainly geared towards Travis CI.
While used in Travis Ci, it does the following:

  • Runs the tests
  • if tests succeed, gets code coverage and sends code coverage to Coveralls and Code Climate
  • if tests succeed and the commit is a new tag, it pusblishes the tag on NPM.


gulp ci
